title: Unilateral Conductive Hearing Loss Post-Tympanomastoidectomy
chief_complaint: I have a history of hearing loss in my left ear due to multiple infections and surgeries. I haven't had a hearing test in over 10 years.

problem_summary.onset: History of multiple ear infections and otosurgeries; tympanomastoidectomy in 2000.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Moderate difficulty receiving speech in the left ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Monitoring stability and evaluation for amplification.

history.present_illness: Patient reports left unilateral hearing loss.
history.otologic_history: Multiple ear infections and otosurgeries in the left ear. Left tympanomastoidectomy completed in 2000.
history.prior_management: Last hearing test was >10 years ago.
history.patient_goals: Evaluation for left ear amplification and HAT.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows normal hearing sensitivity (0-10 dB HL). Left ear shows a moderate to profound conductive hearing loss with normal bone conduction thresholds (0-10 dB HL), indicating a significant air-bone gap.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores are in agreement with PTA for both ears. Word recognition is excellent in both ears when presented at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Immittance testing was not measured due to the surgical history (tympanomastoidectomy).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing sensitivity in the right ear and a moderate-to-profound conductive hearing loss in the left ear. Speech understanding remains excellent in the left ear (96%) when sound is made sufficiently loud to overcome the conductive component. The conductive loss is consistent with the history of chronic otitis media and tympanomastoidectomy.
counseling_points: Your right ear has normal hearing, but your left ear has a 'conductive' hearing loss, meaning the inner ear nerve is working well, but sound isn't getting through the middle ear structures efficiently due to your past surgeries.
Because your word recognition score is excellent (96%) in the left ear, you are a good candidate for a hearing aid, which can make sounds loud enough to overcome that blockage.
We need to obtain medical clearance from an ENT physician before fitting a hearing aid, given your surgical history.
We will schedule an annual hearing test to monitor for any changes.
notes_for_actor: You are a female patient, approx 71 years old.
You are aware your left ear is your 'bad ear' due to many past surgeries.
You are not dizzy and do not have ringing in your ears.
You haven't bothered with a hearing test in a decade but are now open to checking if a device would help.
